title: Nadia Hussain reveals she was asked for a selfie at a funeral while discussing downside of fame
text:
Great British Bake Off star Nadiya Hussain has opened up about the pitfalls of home as she revealed that she was once asked for a selfie at a funeral,

Nadiya, 34, from London, opened up about the challenges of life in the spotlight on food critic Jay Rayner's podcast 'Out to Lunch'.

The mother-of-three admitted her young sons now 'hate' going out in public with her, while her daughter tells her that she 'wishes' Nadiya hadn't won Bake Off.

She also said she has never gotten used to the attention, saying: 'At my sister's best friends funeral, I had someone ask me for a selfie. Can you believe that?'

Great British Bake Off star Nadiya Hussain, 34, from London, said she still struggles with the spotlight, and revealed she was once 'asked for a selfie' at a family friend's funeral

Nadiya, who rose to fame after winning the Great British Bake Off in 2015, said she still struggles with being recognised everywhere she goes.

She has three children together with - sons Musa, ten, and Dawud, nine, and daughter Maryam, six.

She confessed: 'Being recognised is not that easy. My boys absolutely hate going out with me now. They want to do things really quick.'

Nadiya added she rarely felt she could get away from it, saying: 'Even here, in White Chapel, as I was driving here a couple of eyes flick and now some guys who were outside came inside.'

Nadiya said her children continued to struggle with her fame and revealed her sons 'hate' going out in public with her (pictured, with husband Abdal, sons Musa, ten, and Dawud, nine, and daughter Maryam, six)

The mother-of-three admitted: 'You never really get used to that.'

She went on: 'I've been in situations where, for example, at my sister's best friends funeral, I had someone ask me for a selfie. Can you believe that?'

And later, Nadiya explained that her daughter also struggled with fame, saying: 'My little girl still says I wish you'd never won Bake Off.'

The mother-of-three said the comments from her six-year-old daughter were 'a little hurtful'.

Nadiya also revealed there are times that she and her husband Abdal face such intense online abuse she is been left asking 'Why do I put myself through this?'

The mother-of-three opened up about the online abuse she and her husband Abdal face as a result of her fame.

She said: 'With it, it's not been easy, it's been really, really rough. We've had horrible emails, death threats - that's not been fun.

'Those are the points where I question why I've done this - when we get emails threatening me, my husband, my family, I think, why have I put myself through this?'

She admitted she sometimes feels 'sorry' for her husband, who she said 'did not sign up for this', despite her partner being the one who initially sent Nadiya's application form into the show.

The baker admitted she sometimes 'feels sorry' for Abdal, who 'did not sign up to this' and said they had suffered 'really rough' online abuse

Nadiya also suggested that they often suffered abuse from within the Muslim community over her position as 'a breadwinner' in their family.

She said: 'In all cultures men are seen as the breadwinners, they are the one that bring the bacon home I suppose, and the world doesn’t work like that.

'It just isn’t like that anymore. Women work, men work and it’s a partnership and it’s a combination.'
description: Nadiya Hussain, 34, from Luton, told food critic Jay Rayner that she was once asked for a selfie while attending a family friend's funeral. She also admitted her family are still struggling with her fame.
